awd_titl_txt: Youth Engaged in STEM and Service: Locally- and Globally-Relevant Solar Technology Summer Experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
The Youth Engaged in STEM and Service: Locally- and Globally-Relevant Solar Technology Summer Experiences project responds to the pressing need for systems of formal and informal STEM education to support Black, brown, and female-identifying youth with opportunities for youth to build and sustain their interests in STEM beyond required coursework. This project will leverage community-based partnerships to broaden the participation of youth from female-identifying and Black and brown communities through engaging, hands-on solar technology summer camps. The investigators will co-design and implement two summer camp models that engage youth in project-based learning experiences through the lens of either (1) local relevance or (2) global service learning. These camps will operate under the premise that drawing connections to youths’ lived experiences, interests, and globally relevant issues empowers youth to see themselves as someone who can do and be a scientist and engineer. In each of these camp models, youth will learn about electricity, energy, engineering, and solar technology; engage in science and engineering practices; and gain a greater awareness of STEM career pathways. The camps will draw connections to either local issues that directly impact youth’s lived experiences and communities (local relevance), or global social issues with an opportunity to use what they learn to enact social change (global service learning). The Youth Engaged in STEM and Service project aims to contribute to the field’s understanding of the strengths and challenges of two approaches to culturally relevant program design, with important implications for STEM programmatic decision-making. 
 
The research will include a three-part study to examine the design and development, implementation, and learner outcomes of this project. The project will build on the field’s understanding of the key programmatic characteristics and necessary conditions that can support culturally relevant STEM programming for Black and brown and female-identifying youth. Utilizing design-based research, the project will engage in an iterative design process with community-based partners to develop program models for two solar power summer camps, using two approaches to culturally relevant programming: one focused on global service learning and one on local relevance. An implementation study will deepen our understanding of how the features of the two experiences support implementation and youth engagement. Finally, the learner outcomes study will use a quasi-experimental mixed methods approach to examine the impact of camp experiences on youth’s cognitive and social-emotional outcomes. Cognitive outcomes include students’ understanding of STEM content and awareness of STEM career pathways. Social-emotional outcomes include dispositions, interest and identity associated with science. In addition, the study will investigate differential outcomes by gender identity and seek to understand the conditions that attribute to these differences. The study will rely on quantitative and qualitative data including content assessments; observations; interviews; and youth surveys that measure STEM fascination, values, competency beliefs, engagement, and science identity. Outcomes of the project include the research findings as well as curricular resources for hands-on, culturally-relevant summer camps centered around solar technology.

This project is funded by the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program, which supports projects that build understandings of practices, program elements, contexts and processes contributing to increasing students' knowledge and interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and information and communication technology (ICT) careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Youth Engaged in STEM and Service (YESS) was a research-practice partnership to better understand how to design and implement meaningful and affirming informal STEM learning experiences for youth. The project was a collaboration between a public university, four nonprofit organizations, and middle/high school educators. Through a collaborative process, we designed, tested, and refined two culturally responsive and sustaining summer program models that were identical in structure and content, with the exception of their contextualization within either (a) local relevance or (b) global service learning. The local relevance program was framed around connections to environmental issues facing youths’ local community (e.g., wildfires, flooding, droughts) and potential benefits of solar technology. The global service learning program was framed around the lack of access to electricity in global rural areas and included designing a stand-alone solar system to provide solar power for a non-U.S. community.  

In the summers of 2021, 2022, and 2023, 100 middle school students from Alameda, California, gathered at a community-based youth development organization to participate in YESS, a nine-day program where they learned about solar technology and explored the value of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) in their lives, communities, and the world. Designed to support STEM identity development, the hands-on summer program offered culturally relevant and sustaining STEM programming focused on solar technology applications. As part of the research-practice partnership, youth were recruited through local youth-serving organizations, and local teachers collaborated with the project team to design and implement the programs to create a bridge between school-year instruction and the summer programming. 

Drawing on program observations, youth focus groups and interviews, program staff interviews, youth surveys, and program artifacts, the research study focused on the following research questions: 

RQ1: Design-based Research: How can solar-based summer programs be designed to be culturally responsive and sustaining through a local relevance and/or service learning lens? 

RQ2: Implementation Study: How were the programs implemented, and how did program features support student engagement? 

RQ3: Outcomes Study: To what extent did the programs support positive STEM learning outcomes for youth, and were there any differences by program framing or youth characteristics? 

Our study findings illustrated the myriad ways in which tenets of culturally responsive and sustaining pedagogy were observed in the implementation and facilitation of the summer solar program. For instance, educators engaged youth in reflections of their own culture and identity; invited youth to bring in their cultural experiences and practices as they made meaning of solar energy and other scientific phenomena; and utilized engineering design challenges through which youth designed and built solar-based prototypes that addressed real-world issues. Yet, findings also surfaced ways in which the learning environment constrained opportunities to authentically engage youth in conversations about power and privilege in relation to STEM, or how even small moves by educators may have inadvertently delegitimized youths’ cultural knowledge, practices, and expertise, thus contradicting efforts to value and sustain youths' cultural and linguistic practices and ways of being. These findings contribute to understanding the complexities of implementing culturally responsive and sustaining pedagogy in informal learning settings. 

Our findings further indicate that youth engagement across all activities for the two programs was moderate to high, and that youth particularly valued opportunities to build things, do something that could help other people, make new friends, and learn about solar. Youth came away from the learning experiences with greater confidence in their energy/solar knowledge and skills, communication and leadership skills, understanding of culture/identity, and understanding of the broader context (i.e., service learning versus local relevance). Youth also reported significant increases in fascination with, valuing of, competency beliefs in, and innovation stance towards STEM. There were no statistically significant differences between service learning and local relevance programs, or based on youth characteristics such as gender and STEM identity, in any of these youth outcomes. Themes from open-ended responses indicate that contextualization was experienced differently by different youth. For example, in reflecting on their favorite/least favorite parts of the programs, one youth shared “building something that I know will help people all over the world” as their favorite part, while another youth shared an opposing perspective: “I didn't see how learning about refugees [was] related to solar energy/electricity.” 

In summary, our project’s results indicated that the summer programs were able to enact many of the tenets of culturally responsive and sustaining pedagogy within an informal context and in a way that was conducive to engagement, content and skill development, and fostering positive dispositions towards STEM. These findings demonstrate that, while there may be multiple different approaches to make STEM content relevant and engaging, recognizing and affirming individual differences, experiences, and preferences are essential components.
